section.title: Call Pattern
section.para: A call patterncall pattern allows a call to be made within a pattern match.

A pattern x( P0 , … , Pn ), is matched against a value v by calling x.unapply(v), and matching each value published by that call against the tuple pattern ( P0 , … , Pn ). If there is only one pattern P, then P is matched on its own, instead of using a tuple pattern. If there are no patterns, _ is used.
If x.unapply(v) halts silently, or halts without producing any matching values, then the match fails.

If multiple values are published and successfully match, then a multimatchmultimatch occurs: the entire pattern succeeds multiple times. In a function call, the matching clause is executed multiple times, once for each match. In a sequential combinator, the right hand side is executed multiple times, once for each match. In a pruning combinator, one of the matches is chosen arbitrarily.

section.title: Type
section.para: When a call pattern is matched against a type S, the unapply member of the target must have the function type lambda (T) :: (T0 , … , Tn), where S ≤ T. Then each argument pattern Pi is matched against the corresponding type Ti, producing typing contexts Γi. The typing context produced by the whole match is the union of the contexts Γi.
